question.text: A particle <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is projected from the ground with an initial velocity of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> at an angle <math><mn>60</mn><mo>°</mo></math> with horizontal. From what height (in <math><mtext>m</mtext></math>) directly above the point of projection of the particle <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, should another particle <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> be projected horizontally with velocity <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> so that both the particles collide right before they strike the ground? [<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></math>]

solution.text:
Both the particles will meet at C, if their time of flight is the same. The time of flight of A is

T=2usinθg=2×10×sin 6 0 ∘ 10=3s

For vertical downward motion of particle B from B to C

We have

h=12gT2=12 ×10 ×32=15 m
